attributes.value: / This is a synchronization primitive similar to [eventcounts] invented by Dmitry Vyukov.
/ You can use this crate to turn non-blocking data structures into async or blocking data
/ structures. See a [simple mutex] implementation that exposes an async and a blocking interface
/ Wait until another thread sets a boolean flag:
/ // Spawn a thread that will set the flag after 1 second.
/         // Notify all listeners that the flag has been set.
/ // Wait until the flag is set.
/     // Check the flag again after creating the listener.
/     // Wait for a notification and continue the loop.

defs.name: Event
defs.docs: A synchronization primitive for notifying async tasks and threads.

attributes.value: / A synchronization primitive for notifying async tasks and threads.
/ Listeners can be registered using [`Event::listen()`]. There are two ways to notify listeners:
/ 2. [`Event::notify_additional()`] notifies a number of previously unnotified listeners.
/ If there are no active listeners at the time a notification is sent, it simply gets lost.
/ There are two ways for a listener to wait for a notification:
/ 2. In a blocking manner by calling [`EventListener::wait()`] on it.
/ If a notified listener is dropped without receiving a notification, dropping will notify
/ another active listener. Whether one *additional* listener will be notified depends on what
/ Listeners are registered and notified in the first-in first-out fashion, ensuring fairness.

defs.name: listen
defs.docs: Returns a guard listening for a notification.

attributes.value: / Returns a guard listening for a notification.
/ This method emits a `SeqCst` fence after registering a listener.

defs.name: notify
defs.docs: Notifies a number of active listeners.

attributes.value: / Notifies a number of active listeners.
/ The number is allowed to be zero or exceed the current number of listeners.
/ In contrast to [`Event::notify_additional()`], this method only makes sure *at least* `n`
/ listeners among the active ones are notified.
/ This method emits a `SeqCst` fence before notifying listeners.
/ // This notification gets lost because there are no listeners.
/ // Listener queueing is fair, which means `listener1` and `listener2`
/ // get notified here since they start listening before `listener3`.

defs.name: notify_relaxed
defs.docs: Notifies a number of active listeners without emitting a `SeqCst` fence.

attributes.value: / Notifies a number of active listeners without emitting a `SeqCst` fence.
/ The number is allowed to be zero or exceed the current number of listeners.
/ In contrast to [`Event::notify_additional()`], this method only makes sure *at least* `n`
/ listeners among the active ones are notified.
/ Unlike [`Event::notify()`], this method does not emit a `SeqCst` fence.
/ // This notification gets lost because there are no listeners.
/ // We should emit a fence manually when using relaxed notifications.
/ // Listener queueing is fair, which means `listener1` and `listener2`
/ // get notified here since they start listening before `listener3`.

defs.name: notify_additional
defs.docs: Notifies a number of active and still unnotified listeners.

attributes.value: / Notifies a number of active and still unnotified listeners.
/ The number is allowed to be zero or exceed the current number of listeners.
/ In contrast to [`Event::notify()`], this method will notify `n` *additional* listeners that
/ This method emits a `SeqCst` fence before notifying listeners.
/ // This notification gets lost because there are no listeners.
/ // Listener queueing is fair, which means `listener1` and `listener2`
/ // get notified here since they start listening before `listener3`.

defs.name: notify_additional_relaxed
defs.docs:
Notifies a number of active and still unnotified listeners without emitting a `SeqCst`
 fence.

attributes.value: / Notifies a number of active and still unnotified listeners without emitting a `SeqCst`
/ The number is allowed to be zero or exceed the current number of listeners.
/ In contrast to [`Event::notify()`], this method will notify `n` *additional* listeners that
/ Unlike [`Event::notify_additional()`], this method does not emit a `SeqCst` fence.
/ // This notification gets lost because there are no listeners.
/ // We should emit a fence manually when using relaxed notifications.
/ // Listener queueing is fair, which means `listener1` and `listener2`
/ // get notified here since they start listening before `listener3`.

defs.name: EventListener
defs.docs: A guard waiting for a notification from an [`Event`].

attributes.value: / A guard waiting for a notification from an [`Event`].
/ There are two ways for a listener to wait for a notification:
/ 2. In a blocking manner by calling [`EventListener::wait()`] on it.
/ If a notified listener is dropped without receiving a notification, dropping will notify
/ another active listener. Whether one *additional* listener will be notified depends on what

defs.name: wait
defs.docs: Blocks until a notification is received.

attributes.value: / Blocks until a notification is received.

defs.name: wait_timeout
defs.docs: Blocks until a notification is received or a timeout is reached.

attributes.value: / Blocks until a notification is received or a timeout is reached.
/ Returns `true` if a notification was received.
/ // There are no notification so this times out.

defs.name: wait_deadline
defs.docs: Blocks until a notification is received or a deadline is reached.

attributes.value: / Blocks until a notification is received or a deadline is reached.
/ Returns `true` if a notification was received.
/ // There are no notification so this times out.

defs.name: discard
defs.docs:
Drops this listener and discards its notification (if any) without notifying another
 active listener.

attributes.value: / Drops this listener and discards its notification (if any) without notifying another
/ Returns `true` if a notification was discarded.

defs.name: listens_to
defs.docs: Returns `true` if this listener listens to the given `Event`.

attributes.value: / Returns `true` if this listener listens to the given `Event`.

defs.name: same_event
defs.docs: Returns `true` if both listeners listen to the same `Event`.

attributes.value: / Returns `true` if both listeners listen to the same `Event`.
